titlestmt.titleproper:
Guide to the Alpha Delta Phi Records,
1832 - 2017

titlepage.titleproper: Guide to the Alpha Delta Phi Records, 1832 - 2017
titlepage.publisher:
Special Collections & Archives
Wesleyan University
Middletown, CT, USA

did.head: Descriptive Summary
did.physloc: For current information on the location of these materials, please consult Special Collections & Archives staff.
did.abstract: The Alpha Delta Phi Records consist of materials related to the Middletown Chapter at Wesleyan University including its alumni groups, the Adelphic Educational Fund (AEF) and the Adelphic Literary Society (ALS). Ranging from 1832 - 2017, the materials include correspondence, minutes, annual reports, constitutions, by-laws, handbooks, manuals, invitations, newspaper and article clippings, photographs, postcards, publications, songbooks, histories, shirts, event posters, architectural drawings, banners, audio recordings, video recordings, and realia. The records cover the history of the chapter through its formation, development and management of the ALS and AEF, management of its eating club The Star & Crescent, its involvement with co-education, the split with the Alpha Delta Phi International Fraternity, the formation of the Alpha Delta Phi Society, and its relations with Wesleyan University.

accessrestrict.head: Access Restrictions
accessrestrict.p: Materials are closed for 75 years from the date of creation.

userestrict.head: Copyright Notice
userestrict.p: Copyright for official University records is held by Wesleyan University; all other copyright is retained by the authors of items in these papers, or their descendants, as stipulated by United States copyright law.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: [Identification of item], Alpha Delta Phi Records, Special Collections & Archives, Wesleyan University, Middletown, CT, USA.

acqinfo.head: Acquisitions Information
acqinfo.p: On deposit to the Special Collections & Archives from The Adelphic Literary Society of Wesleyan University, of Middletown, Connecticut, and The Adelphic Educational Fund, Incorporated. Materials were acquired from 2016-2017.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: The Alpha Delta Phi Records were partially processed by ADP Archivist Michaelle Biddle in the late 2000s. Most recent processing and encoding was completed by Stephanie T. Gold in 2016-2017. Original order and folder titles were maintained in most cases. Dates and other information added by the processor are found in square brackets. Items that were added to the collection during processing were inserted into the relevant series and sub-series. Items found in Series VIII: Members that could fill gaps within Series I: AEF, Series II: ALS, or Series III: Chapter were removed and integrated into those series. Notes were left in the files to mark the item and state where the item was moved to. Duplicate materials in excess of three copies were permanently removed from the collection. Notes were left in the files to mark the item and state where the item was moved to. In series XIV: Publications, four Wesleyan University catalogs were permanently removed from the collection due to excessive mold damage. Other items that contained mold were temporarily removed, properly cleaned and returned to the collection.

bioghist.head: Historical Note
bioghist.p: The Middletown Chapter of the Alpha Delta Phi has served as a literary society to Wesleyan University students since its founding on July 31, 1856. At the 1856 Alpha Delta Phi convention in New Haven, Connecticut, two Wesleyan debating societies known as the Betrian Society and the Lebanian Society petitioned the International organization of Alpha Delta Phi for inclusion in the nationwide fraternity. It was decided to merge the two societies and a charter was granted to form the Middletown Chapter as the 18th chapter of the International. The two societies already had common ground with dining at the Chronometer Club and so merging the two worked with ease.

The new chapter moved quickly to renting halls in downtown Middletown for its meetings. In 1884, after the establishment and success of the Building Fund, the chapter erected its first house located on the former Neale property on the corner of High and Cross Streets. In this house, the chapter rented out rooms, held meetings and other events, and dined in its eating club The Star & Crescent Club for almost 20 years until numerous costly repairs necessitated the chapter to tear down the structure. Immediately, plans were drawn up for a larger house located on the same property. The second Middletown Chapter house was completed in 1905 and still houses ADP members and hosts meetings, reunions, weddings, and other Wesleyan or ADP related events.

In 1881 a group of Alpha Delta Phi alumni founded the Adelphic Literary Society (ALS) to support the intellectual and moral improvement of its members by developing ties among the undergraduate and post graduate members of the chapter. With the incorporation of the ALS chartered by the Legislature of the State of Connecticut, the ALS could legally own, maintain and transfer property for the Middletown Chapter, which it successfully did to allow the building of the chapter houses for undergraduate members. The ALS is also responsible for the chapter's eating club, the Star & Crescent, and it connects with its undergraduate members through alumni events on and off campus and serving as mentors.

As a way to sponsor intellectual growth of chapter members through public and educational activities at Wesleyan University, the Adelphic Educational Fund, Inc. (AEF) was established on December 14, 1944, and has since continued the support of intellectual and social life at Wesleyan. The tax-exempt AEF was founded by alumni led by George W. Davison, 1892, and Albert W. Johnston, 1893, to aid deserving undergraduates in the attainment of a college education at Wesleyan, with a preference for members of the Middletown Chapter of the Alpha Delta Phi. In addition to educational funding made available to students through the grant-in-aid program, the AEF also funds the Middletown Chapter's literary publication AdLit, literary events such as the Assembly Series, a Faculty Fellows program, and a community service program. It also funded educational programs which are now defunct, such as the Film Series and a Science Series.

Since its formation in 1856, the Middletown Chapter dealt with local and national issues. Undergraduate members lived years through wars, financial depressions, political unrest and fraternity tensions. During these times, the members came together to support one another and strived to come out on top. In the 1960s and 1970s when co-education was making waves across American universities and colleges, the Middletown Chapter began welcoming women members from Wesleyan's re-imagined co-ed student body, resulting in what is known among ADP members and alumni as the Co-Education Issue. While the International held firm against any of its chapters going co-ed, the undergraduate members of the Middletown Chapter endorsed the inclusion of women members. From 1972 until 1992, there was a constant debate to acknowledge women into the International, a struggle that ended in a split. On August 7, 1992 at the 160th Alpha Delta Phi Convention in Brainerd, Minnesota, a contract was approved by a 41-0 vote acknowledging the withdrawal of four chapters that wished to become co-educational chapters. These four co-educational chapters, Brunonian, Columbia, Middletown and Stanford, made up the newly formed Alpha Delta Phi Society. Other chapters would later leave the national fraternity and join the Society.

In 2006, the Middletown Chapter celebrated its sesquicentennial where they hosted a reunion, conducted oral history interviews, and published a history on the chapter's meeting and living areas titled Halls, Houses & Eating Clubs.

scopecontent.head: Collection Overview
scopecontent.p: The Alpha Delta Phi Records contain materials created or collected by members of the Middletown Chapter, the Adelphic Literary Society and the Adelphic Educational Fund and span from 1832-2017. Items found in the collection include correspondence, minutes, annual reports, constitutions, by-laws, handbooks, manuals, invitations, newspaper and article clippings, photographs, postcards, publications, songbooks, histories, shirts, event posters, architectural drawings, banners, audio recordings, video recordings, and realia. Audio and visual recordings found in the collection are in the format of reel to reel tape, audiocassette tapes, CD-Roms, videotapes and DVDs. The media format for these items is noted at the folder level. The records are housed in 154 archival document boxes, and 62 custom or oversize boxes.

Of note are the records of or created by Robert G. McKelvey, 1959. Through his years of service to the Middletown Chapter along with his roles of ALS President, AEF President, International President and Society President, Robert McKelvey's records cover many issues that faced the undergraduate and alumni body from the early 1970s to the present. Such issues included the rebuilding of the ALS, establishing a distinct division between the ALS and AEF, reducing debt, developing fundraising among the alumni, navigating the chapter and the International through the co-educational issue, and assisting with the formation of the Alpha Delta Phi Society. Also of note are the records of or created by William K. Wasch, 1952. Through his years of service to the Middletown Chapter along with his roles of Secretary/Treasurer for both the ALS and AEF, his files cover a significant portion of the organizations' histories along with a variety of issues that faced the Middletown Chapter including the transformation of the Society as it broke away from the Fraternity, the monumental debt reduction campaigns of the early 1990s and the financial struggles of the Star & Crescent Club throughout that decade.

arrangement.head: Collection Arrangement
arrangement.p: The records are arranged into 14 series which are found alphabetical by series name. Most of the 14 series have further been arranged in sub-series which are arranged alphabetically. Due to the variety of filing schemes practiced by the numerous contributors to this collection, files and papers are found in both chronological and reverse chronological order.

list.item: Series III: Chapter - Alpha Delta Phi - Middletown Chapter, 1856 - , 1856-2017

scopecontent.p: This series consists of the records created by members of the Adelphic Educational Fund, Inc., including the founding of the AEF, meeting minutes, by-laws, grant-in-aid applications, events sponsored by the AEF, financial documents and newspaper clippings. Materials for this series are housed in 12 document boxes, 5 linear feet.
See also: Series II: ALS - Swain (Joseph R. Swain ALS Secretary-Treasurer 1948-1983)

Series III: Chapter - Alpha Delta Phi - Middletown Chapter, 1856 - , 1856-2017

scopecontent.p: This series consists of records created by the undergraduate members of the Middletown Chapter of the Alpha Delta Phi. Also included are records related to the Star & Crescent, the chapter's eating club. Materials found within this series include the charter; constitution & by-laws; meeting minutes; correspondence; financial records; officer records, handbooks and manuals; invitations; time capsule and publications. Materials for this series are housed in 50 document boxes and two oversize boxes, 25.5 linear feet.
See also Series VII: Ledgers
Contains VHS & tape reel.

This series includes correspondence, histories, and newspaper clippings related to the debate to incorporate women members into the Alpha Delta Phi International. Materials for this series are housed in two document boxes, .83 linear feet.
See also Series VIII: Members - Personal Papers - Polin, Jane

This series contains the records related to the fundraising, purchasing, building, maintenance, and furnishing of both houses built by the Middletown Chapter, the first in 1884 and the second in 1904. Items found in this series include correspondence, architectural drawings, deeds, maps and mortgages. Materials for this series are housed in six document boxes and one oversize box, 5.5 linear feet.
See also Series V: House & Property - Renovations

This series contains the recordings of accounts for members, treasurers and the Star & Crescent Eating Club. These accounts were recorded in bound ledgers, with the exception of one folder of unbound ledger sheets. Materials for this series are housed in one document box and 15 oversize boxes, 9.4 linear feet.

This series contains records related to or of undergraduate or after graduate members and includes AEF, ALS and Chapter related records of officers; correspondence; article clippings; newspaper clippings; postcards; pins; a scrapbook; and realia. The Vertical File sub-series contains materials that were collected by those other than the named individual and may have been added to over a period of time. The Personal Papers sub-series consists of materials created and organized by the named individual, most of whom are past ALS Presidents. Materials for this series are housed in 65 document boxes and three custom or oversize boxes, 32 linear feet.

Herbert A. Arnold served as a board member of the ALS and was Chairman of the Scholarship Committee. His files span from 1980-1991.
Johnson Cooper served as Chairman of Membership & Alumni Records Committee for the ALS. His records range from 1974-1982.
These records cover Coulombe's time as Historian for the Chapter.

The files of Jenny Flannigan cover her tenure as President of the ALS from 1996 October 19 - 2002 June, include the First Society Annual Convention which was hosted by the Middletown Chapter and document the extensive and major renovations to the Chapter House. Jenny also served as a board member of the AEF. These files span from 1992-2003.
Contains VHS videotapes.

scopecontent.p: Contains VHS.

Robert G. McKelvey became president of the ALS in 1971 and of the AEF in 1974. The ALS and the AEF had functionally collapsed into one organization. This situation threatened the tax-exempt status of the AEF. The late 1960s and early 1970s were restless times at Wesleyan and the chapter was affected. The files cover a make or break period of the chapter's history.

The files below were accessioned at a later date from the initial accession of records. These files were created or collected during McKelvey's time as AEF President from 1971-2015, span from 1884-2015 and have been kept in original order of alphabetical and chronological arrangement.

scopecontent.p: The records of Jane Polin '80 are from her undergraduate years as chairman on different committees for the Chapter, with a small amount of material from post graduate years as a board member of the ALS. The records range from 1978-1986.
The records of Don Spencer '77 cover his time as ALS President from 1994-1996 with a small amount of material from later years as a board member of the ALS. The records range from 1977-1999.

The records of James L. Steffenson cover his time serving in a variety of capacities such as board member of the ALS, Chairman of the Scholarship Committee, and Faculty Advisor to the House. The records range from 1974-1980 and are arranged in reverse chronological order.

Bill Wasch '52 became Secretary of the ALS in 1984 and Secretary of the AEF in 1988, though he had been a member of both organizations' boards since the late 1960s. He later became the Treasurer of both the ALS and AEF. He has been Secretary/Treasurer for a significant portion of both organizations' histories, so his files cover a wide variety of events. These files include the transformation of the Society as it broke away from the Fraternity, the monumental debt reduction campaigns of the early 1990s and the financial struggles of the Star & Crescent throughout that decade. These files span from 1944-2007 and are arranged in alphabetical and chronological order.
The files of Jeffrey Yaus consist of records created or collected during his time as ALS President from 2002-2005. The records span from 1970-2005.

The files of Eric Yuhas '88 consist of records created or collected during his time as Chapter House Manager, Treasurer and President, with the earlier records possibly passed on by previous presidents. The records span from 1978-1988.

did.unittitle: 146th Convention, Building A Strong Alumni Organization, 1978

scopecontent.p: The 1978 annual convention was hosted by the Middletown Chapter.

These items consist of a coffeepot and sugar pot and email correspondence between Frederick Burnham's grandson and Leslie Starr regarding the acquisition of those personal items, which belonged to Frederick, class of 1912, and his wife, Ramona Hubbard, and are believed to have been given as a gift from the ADP, Middletown Chapter.
These items consist of two pins and a brief typed biography of John Edward Eustis, class of 1874.
These items consist of a pin and email correspondence regarding the acquisition of an ADP pin of Frank Littell, class of 1891. Found within the email correspondence is a brief biography on Littell.
Materials for this series are housed in five oversize boxes, 3.5 linear feet.

These t-shirts are tie-dyed pledge shirts, basic APD logo shirts and shirts from International or Society conventions. The shirts have been grouped dated and undated and are arranged in chronological order when dates are provided.

Includes photographs and negatives of Alpha Delta Phi members, places, and events. When photographs were found within other series, the photographs were removed from those files and placed in Series X: Photographs. A separation sheet was inserted where the items were removed to note what was moved and to where. When possible, groups of photographs were kept together and labeled accordingly, i.e. House & Property, Members. Materials for this series are housed in three document boxes and two oversize boxes, 3.6 linear feet.

Front Porch Project, work that still needs to be done at the House, 2005

scopecontent.p: These photographs are either 3x5 or 4x6 and are mostly undated and unidentified.

These files consist of the records created after the Middletown Chapter left the International and joined the Society. Materials include constitution, convention records, correspondence, and publications. Materials for this series are housed in four document boxes, 1.7 linear feet.
See also Series IV: Co-Educational Issue.
This series includes songs & songbooks for Alpha Delta Phi and for Wesleyan University. Materials for this series are housed in three document boxes and two custom boxes, 3 linear feet.

did.unittitle: Official Alpha Delta Phi Christmas Carols, 1997 December

unittitle.title: The Songs of Alpha Delta Phi

scopecontent.p: The Songs of Alpha Delta Phi was originally released as a set of three 78 RPM records. Unfortunately, no date is printed on the record labels, so we do not know when these recordings were made. Because the lyrics of We Come With A Shout And A Song require the singers to insert the name of their college, we know that the performers are from the Cornell chapter. The authors, where known, are listed as they appear in the Song Book of Alpha Delta Phi published in 1912.
Contains CDs.

The records in this series document the relations, agreements, and events between Wesleyan University and the Alpha Delta Phi Middletown Chapter or more generally fraternities on campus represented by the Board of House Presidents. Items include correspondence, meeting minutes, reports, event programs and invitations, and newspaper clippings. Materials for this series are housed in two document boxes, .83 linear feet.

This series includes publications other than songbooks of Alpha Delta Phi International and/or the Middletown Chapter and Wesleyan University publications. Materials for this series are housed in six document boxes and seven custom boxes, 3.2 linear feet.
